+ [mul1] [class1] associate [mul2] [class2] (class1 and2 are classes above. mul1 and mul2 are one of the following options[0..*

A smart home automation system (SHAS) offers various users to automatically manage smart home automation tasks. A smart home (located at a physical address) consists of several rooms
column2: each of which may contain sensor devices and actuator (controller) devices of different types (e.g. temperature sensor
column5: lock controller). Each sensor and actuator have a unique device identifier. Once a new sensor or actuator is activated or deactivated
column6: SHAS will recognize the change and update its infrastructure map.

column2: a sensor device periodically provides sensor readings (recording the measured value and the timestamp). Similarly
column3: a predefined set of control commands (e.g. lockDoor
column4: turnOnHeating) can be sent to the actuator devices with the timestamp and the status of the command (e.g. requested
column7: etc.). All sensor readings and control commands for a smart home are recorded by SHAS in an activity log.

column1: Relevant alerts in a smart home can be set up and managed by its owner by setting up automation rules. An automation rule has a precondition and an action. The precondition is a Boolean expression constructed from relational terms connected by basic Boolean operators (AND
column3: NOT). Atomic relational terms may refer to rooms
column6: sensor readings and control commands. The action is a sequence of control commands. For example

column1: when actualTemperature by Device #1244 in Living Room < 18 and window is closed

column3: activated and deactivated by owners. Only deactivated rules can be edited. Rules can also depend on or conflict with other rules
column4: thus a complex rule hierarchy can be designed. SHAS records whenever an active rule was triggered using a timestamp.
